abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Tanzania - Sixth
            Power Project were as follows: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, the Bank and
            borrower performance were both unsatisfactory. The lessons
            learned indicate that given two generation options with
            nearly equal economic benefits, the operating experience of
            the implementing agency should be given considerable weight
            relative to other factors in deciding on the most viable
            generation option. Prepayment metering can be an effective
            technical solution to power company billing and collection
            problems but configuration in line with the tariff structure
            and loopholes for fraud should be given priority attention
            in the design of the system. The form of institutional
            development assistance in a power project should depend on
            the individual country situation as well as a realistic
            assessment of what can be achieved during the project's
            implementation period. In general, standard investment loans
            are not appropriate lending vehicles to pursue privatization
            objectives, especially the construction of a large
            hydropower plant. All hydropower projects with dams, by
            their very nature, are bound to have a deleterious impact on
            the environment in some way and assessments should reflect a
            consensus of Bank and Borrower policies on the amount of
            damage that is acceptable to meet human needs for electric
            power. The original Environmental Assessment, undertaken in
            1991 prior to appraisal, was approved by regional management
            and subsequently by the Bank's board. In retrospect,
            the supervision of the Power VI project suffered from the
            lack of a Bank environmental specialist as a permanent
            member of the supervision team. The failure to define water
            rights at an earlier stage of project construction, ideally
            before construction began, left unresolved the differing
            water requirements of energy generation for the dam and
            conservation requirements in the downstream area of the
            Kihansi gorge. Despite the original assessment of minimal
            environmental impact, Power VI also took note of a lesson
            learned at appraisal that continued ecological monitoring
            during project implementation was important.

repnme.cdata!: Tanzania - Sixth Power Project : Management Response

abstracts.cdata!:
Management Response for the Tanzania
            Sixth Power Project examines the claims made by the
            Requestors in the Request for Inspection and the results of
            the Investigation Report.  The Management Response addresses
            the eligibility of the Requesters, citing that many of the
            Requesters did not have or claim residency from the affected
            areas. The Management also examines the Request and whether
            there were violations of policies and procedures. Annexes
            highlight each alleged violation, environmental
            requirements, and the impacts of gas development on
            biophysical environments.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Sixth Power Project : Request
            for Inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Request for Inspection for the
            Tanzania Power VI Project, filed by a group of individuals
            from Tannol Holdings, Ltd., states that the International
            Development Association (IDA) has failed to follow
            operational policies.  The IDA financed an Emergency Power
            Project (EEP) in Tanzania and, according to the Requesters,
            intervened improperly and have caused great financial loss
            and injury to the Requesters. Since 1992 a consortium of two
            Canadian companies has been considering a gas field and
            pipeline project known as the Songo Songo Project. Under the
            terms of this project, one of the consortium members, Ocelot
            Energy and Transcanada Pipelines (OTC) would be given 50
            percent interest in the gas field that is being developed
            with IDA money. The project was projected to be funded by
            private funds, but in early 1995 a letter from the Bank to
            the Tanzania Ministry of Water, Energy and Materials stated
            that all World Bank aid would be cut off unless the Canadian
            OTC project with IDA funding was selected. Despite repeated
            reassurance from the Bank that the matter would be justified
            or countermanded, the Tanzanian Ministry of Water and Energy
            announced that the OTC project had been selected. The
            Requesters claim the IDA failed to follow operational
            policies and providing funding for a government-owned power
            plant when a private sector project could have been
            constructed from private sources. The Requesters also cite
            the failure to follow environmental assessments used by the
            Bank because the OTC project will be constructed on an
            unsound site with no previous environmental assessments and
            at a cost to public health and safety.

docna.cdata!: Tanzania - Sixth Power Project : Request for Inspection

repnme.cdata!: Tanzania - Sixth Power Project : Eligibilty Report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Eligibility Report for the Power VI
            Project in Tanzania outlines the Request for Inspection and
            provides recommendations based on the Inspection
            Panel's investigation. The Request, filed by a group
            from a Tanzanian company, Tannol Holdings, LTC., claimed
            that restructuring of the loan for the Power VI Project was
            not necessary as private funding was available and was not
            considered by the Management.  The Requesters state that the
            International Development Association (IDA) did not follow
            policies and procedures and improperly influenced the
            Tanzanian Government's decision in regards to funding
            for the project. The Requesters also claim that the
            Bank's environmental policies were violated in
            preparation for the project. After reviewing the Request,
            the Panel is satisfied that Management has followed the
            required policies and procedures in regards to environmental
            assessment. The Panel concluded that an investigation into
            the violations of the IDA policies is not recommended.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are
            to: (a) help meet the growing demand for electricity at
            least cost; (b) help the government restructure the power
            sector to promote efficiency and private investment; (c)
            continue improving energy efficiency by reducing system
            losses, upgrading service quality, and supporting demand
            side management initiatives; (d) provide training and
            technology to staff of sector institutions; and (e) promote
            the development and operation of gas-fueled generation by
            private investors. The project consists of three main parts.
            The first part, which the Tanzania Electric Supply Company
            Ltd. (TANESCO) will implement, includes: (1) the 180 MW
            first stage of the Lower Kihansi hydroelectric scheme; (2)
            expansion, reinforcement, and loss reduction in the
            distribution systems of major load centers; (3) vehicles,
            tools, and meters to improve distribution and commercial
            operations; (4) completion of rehabilitation of the Kidatu
            hydroelectric plant; (5) management support and training;
            (6) computerized management information systems, and
            services to support TANESCO's decentralized operations;
            (7) studies including tariffs, assets valuation, power
            system master plan, hydroelectric plant feasibility, and
            distribution standards; (8) demand side management
            activities, including audits and advertising; (9) upgrading
            of the dispatch center; and (10) provision of workshop
            equipment. The second part, which the Zanzibar State Fuel
            and Power Corporation (ZSFPC) will implement, includes: (a)
            a study of the operation of ZSFPC to define feasible options
            for its future structure; (b) a commercial manager to
            oversee commercial operations until the completion of the
            utility restructuring; and (c) prepayment meters and
            associated materials to help improve collections. The third
            part, which the Ministry of Water, Energy, and Minerals
            (MWEM) will implement, includes: (1) a study of the
            structure of the power sector and its associated regulatory
            framework in Tanzania to define options for restructuring to
            improve efficiency, and to explore ways of involving the
            private sector; (2) consulting services to promote private
            sector financing and operation of thermal generation using
            gas from Songo Songo; (3) development of generation (about 9
            MW) from the Mnazi bay gasfield in a joint arrangement with
            the private sector; and (4) training and office technology
            for energy staff of the ministry.
